Evaluating marketplaces? Look for:
- founder execution
- access to capital
- shared supply/demand across niches/locations
- access to supply
Marketplaces are hard to evaluate‚Äîespecially as their recent popularity has led to a clone-factory atmosphere.
Marketplaces and Payments businesses are timeless. There will consistently be billion dollar companies started in both areas.

9/ when immediate risks or clear bad behavior exists (eg fantasy gaming) regulators should step in. Otherwise, develop better understanding.
8/ I think a good regulatory framework would involve regulators sharing community concerns and coaching companies.
7/ Both sides have a motive to resolve quickly, but the best policy comes from waiting and understanding the real effects of the change.
6/ Regulators own much of the blame as well ‚Äî knee jerk reactions, status quo & loss aversion bias, not engaging/learning enough.

5/ Assuming self-regulation will be ok only leads to large fights later*.

_
*: Sometimes this is a good strategy to buy time & prove value.
4/ Tech is much more altruistic than traditional industries. Good motives coupled with this fear of risk, create a desire to self-regulate.

3/ Unlike trad. businesses, Tech relies on capital that looks for massively decreased risk every 18-24mo.

Regulatory risk can be fatal.
2/ business is very good at rapidly improving life for customers, but not good at understanding/valuing potential negative externalities.
1/ Regulation is important, good, and something tech deeply undervalues. We should embrace & work with regulators to find equilibrium.

FN/ 
1. Changing your location can be done via moving or via travel. 
2. Don't forget to factor family and lifestyle into "desired outcome."
9/ as an individual, we are all more mobile than ever. Change your location to reflect your situation and desired outcome.
8/ as an industry, we have culturally unhealthy views on where you should be and how you should grow. Don't blindly follow the blog advice.
7/ SF happens to be the best place for achieving huge growth rates, but if you're not on that track, you're probably at a disadvantage here.
6/ popular belief will tell you this is a failure - but the vast majority of great companies are built over long, slow, unsexy slogs.
5/ if and when you stutter during acceleration, you may want to migrate back to a lower cost market where you can invest in growing slowly.
4/ probably the best model as an entrepreneur is to build elsewhere and migrate to SF when you have the opportunity to accelerate (e.g. YC).
3/ for incubation, the SF Bay Area is a lot worse. It's expensive and it's very hard to get and keep talent (you will make mistakes here).
2/ for acceleration, there is no better place to be than the SF bay area. You can recruit more experienced talent and get better advice.

You learn faster by doing, but you never learn what your personal deficiencies are without watching. (Founders are often guilty of this).
Watching is key for knowing the totality of what must be learned.
Teaching is the best way to crystallize it in your head, and it's hard to master it without figuring out how to teach it.
If you're learning something, find a way to get all three, even if your manager's not  creating the opportunity for you to do it.
Even if they haven't mastered it yet, have them try to teach it to someone (the rest of the team, an intern, their kid sister, whomever).
Then watch them do it, give feedback after the fact. More reps here will make a person better rapidly.
Let the person watch an expert do it first, so they see what success actually looks like. If possible, break it down as its happening.
How to mentor someone in a new skill set: watch one, do one, teach one.

Optionality is harder to define, but look for access to experiences, information, relationships, or audiences that are unique & valuable.
Free cash flow means quickly profitable, & can generate enough cash to fund your lifestyle. Then optimize for more $, or automate the work.
Very large scale means, in my definition, that you think you can eventually get to at least 50-100m/yr in revenues.
Each of those concepts can be hard to judge if you're not familiar with them.
Very large scale is the only one of those three that is venture backable, but all three can provide lots of value to the founder/team.
When considering building a business, look for opportunities that provide either future optionality, free cash flow, or very large scale.
